title: If a number is multiplied by three-fourth of itself, the value thus obtained is 10800. What is that number? - Quora

response.answer_text: The other answers so far aren't hopeless, but they do miss the possibility of a negative solution. Say we are looking for real-number solutions: we then have [math]x (\frac{3}{4}x) = 10800[/math] Multiplication on the real numbers is commutative: [math]x (x\frac{3}{4}) = 10800[/math] And associative: [math](x x)\frac{3}{4} = 10800[/math] [math]\frac{3}{4}[/math] has a (right-) multiplicative inverse [math]\frac{4}{3}[/math], so use it: [math]((x x)(\frac{3}{4})\frac{4}{3} = 10800 \frac{4}{3}[/math] Associative property again: [math](x x)(\frac{3}{4}\frac{4}{3}) = 10800 \frac{4}{3}[/math] We know what multiplicative inverses do: [math](x x)1 = 10800 \frac{4}{3}[/math] We know what [math]1[/math], the multiplicative (right-)identity does: [math]x x = 10800 \frac{4}{3}[/math] We haven't forgotten how to do arithmetic with fractions, and we know what [math]{}^2[/math] means: [math]x^2 = 14400[/math] [math]x^2 = (-x)^2[/math] (true in any ring), so if [math]x[/math] is a solution, so also is [math]-x[/math]. [math]x = \pm \sqrt{14400} = \pm 120[/math]
